metadata.title: PLOS ONE Seroprevalence of COVID-19 infection in a rural district of South India: a community- based cross-sectional study

abstract.text: We aimed to estimate the seroprevalence of COVID-19 in a rural district of South India, six month after the index case. Methodology We conducted a cross-sectional study of 509 adults aged more than 18 years. From all the four subdistricts, two grampanchayats (administrative cluster of 5-8 villages) were randomly selected followed by one village through convenience. The participants were invited for the study to the community-based study kiosk set up in all the eight villages through village health committees. We collected socio-demographic characteristics and symptoms using a mobile application-based questionnaire, and we tested samples for the presence of IgG antibodies for SARS CoV-2 using an electro chemiluminescent immunoassay. We calculated age-gender adjusted and test performance adjusted seroprevalence.

The age-and gender-adjusted seroprevalence was 8.5% (95% CI 6.9%-10.8%).The unadjusted seroprevalence among participants with hypertension and diabetes was 16.3% (95% CI:9.2-25.8) and 10.7 % (95% CI: 5.5-18.3) respectively.When we adjusted for the test performance, the seroprevalence was 6.1% (95% CI 4.02 -8.17). The study estimated 7 (95% CI 1:4.5 -1

body_text.text: The authors have declared that no competing interests exist. NO Objectives 28 We aimed to estimate the seroprevalence of COVID-19 in a rural district of South India, six 29 month after the index case.

We conducted a cross-sectional study of 509 adults aged more than 18 years. From all the 32 four subdistricts, two grampanchayats (administrative cluster of 5-8 villages) were randomly 33 selected followed by one village through convenience. The participants were invited for the 34 study to the community-based study kiosk set up in all the eight villages through village 35 health committees. We collected socio-demographic characteristics and symptoms using a 36 mobile application-based questionnaire, and we tested samples for the presence of IgG 37 antibodies for SARS CoV-2 using an electro chemiluminescent immunoassay. We calculated 38 age-gender adjusted and test performance adjusted seroprevalence.
The age-and gender-adjusted seroprevalence was 8.5% (95% CI 6.9%-10.8%).The

There has been substantial evidence that a large proportion of the people infected with SARS 85 CoV-2 are asymptomatic, but they can infect others. It has been reported based on an analysis 86 of 21 published reports that asymptomatic cases could account from 5 to 80% [5] . It is crucial study to estimate a seroprevalence in Bangalore rural district six months after the index case. 115 We also hope the findings of this study will help the health authorities in disease containment 116 and add valuable data to researchers across the globe.
Setting 119 The study was conducted in Bangalore Rural District of Karnataka, a South Indian State.

This district is located close to Bangalore city and is divided into four sub-districts (taluks) (adults ≥18years) from houses to give blood samples. If a household refused to participate, then the next house was approached. In each cluster, mobilisation continued till the desired 148 sample size was achieved in each village. We aimed to include 63 adults from each of these 149 villages, adding up to 126 in each sub-district. 150 We met with the village health committees and discussed the purpose of the study and 151 enlisted their cooperation. Together with the community, we decided that kiosk-based 152 recruitment of the participants was more practical due to strict restriction on the movement of 153 the people by the state government. People were also apprehensive about the health team 154 from cities visiting their homes and increasing the risk of transmission of the disease. 155 We recruited people after explaining the purpose of the study, took written consent and then 156 interviewed people with a questionnaire by a trained research coordinator who had previous 157 training in data collection. An Epi-info mobile application-based tool was used to capture 158 responses offline by the interviewer, and it was later downloaded for analysis.

The questionnaire contained questions about demographic information (age, gender, Sample processing and analysis 167 The serum was separated and used to test for antibodies using the Elecsys Anti SARS CoV2 Table) . IgM is reported to occur simultaneously or sequentially [18, 19] . Assuming a three-week lag The overall seroprevalence of for COVID-19 was 12.4% (95 % CI 9.6-15.6) ( Table. 2) The 231 age-and gender-adjusted seroprevalence was 8.5% (95% CI 6.9%-10.8%) (S.1 Table) We estimated that the cumulative number of SARS CoV-2 (Severe acute respiratory Our study estimated that there were 5 to 9 undetected infected individuals for every RT safety measures and access to vaccination is of paramount importance.
The study has potential biases. Though all the subdistricts were selected, and subsequently 330 villages were randomly selected, we employed convenience sampling at the village level.

Villages were apprehensive about the medical team from the city, and hence we enrolled 332 based on individual preference. This would have resulted in selection bias; however, we tried 333 to reduce the bias by calculating age-gender adjusted seroprevalence. Another possibility is 334 the occurrence of measurement bias in estimating seroprevalence. Since we have not done 335 RT-PCR, we would have missed the current infection and underestimated the prevalence.
Measurement bias can also be due to validity parameters of the test, which we have addressed 337 through test performance adjusted seroprevalence.
There are many strengths to this study. This is one of the earliest population-based 339 seroprevalence study conducted in a rural district of India harbouring a million people. This

This study has a few limitations. We did not follow a strict probability sampling technique 345 due to feasibility reasons. Another limitation is that we did not estimate the current infection 346 using RT-PCR. Both these aspects have an effect on the true estimation of seroprevalence in this community. Another limitation is that we have limited our research to one rural district; 348 hence the generalisation of the findings has to be done with caution.

Infection 45 Fatality Rate (IFR) was calculated as 12.38 per 10000 infections as on 22 October 2020. 46 Except for the history of self-reported symptoms, age, gender education, occupation, 47presence of comorbidities were not associated with positive status (p-value >0.05).

FIGREF3.text: proportion of the rural population in a district of south India remains susceptible 50 to COVID-19. A higher proportion of susceptible, relatively higher IFR and a poor tertiary 51 healthcare network stress the importance of sustaining the public health measures and 52 promoting early access to the vaccine are crucial to preserving the health of this population. 53 Low population density, good housing, adequate ventilation, limited urbanisation combined 54 with public, private and local health leadership are critical components of curbing future 55 respiratory pandemics.

FIGREF4.text: disease (COVID-19) was declared as a global pandemic by the World Health 79 Organization on 11 March 2020 [1]. Globally, more than 60 million confirmed cases of 80 COVID-19, including 1,416,292 deaths, have been reported to WHO as of 26 November 81 2020.[2] India has reported more than 9.2 million cases with more than with 135,223 deaths 82 and Karnataka-a south Indian state had 894,137 cases with 8,512 deaths as of 26 November 83 2020 [3,4].

FIGREF5.text: 87to recognise an infected person early and break the route of transmission to control COVID-88 19. However, in reality, they do not require or seek medical attention and contribute to the 89 rapid spread of the disease [6]. Hence, health authorities cannot totally rely on confirmed 90 cases of COVID-19 detected by RT-PCR as it could potentially miss asymptomatic and pre-91 symptomatic infections for containment measures. In order to overcome this challenge, WHO 92 and others have recommended population-based seroepidemiological studies to generate data 93 and to implement containment measures accordingly [7]. These surveys also can give us an 94 estimation of the proportion of the population still susceptible to the infection as it is assumed 95 that antibodies provide immunity. 96 Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) has conducted a nationwide serosurvey among 97 21 states and reported a population-weighted seroprevalence of 0.73% between May and June 98 2020.[8] While a hospital-based survey from Srinagar, northern India has estimated gender-preventive health services through a Rural Health centre and network of mobile 103 clinics to residents of Bangalore rural district over a decade. CHD also runs special programs 104 for chronic diseases, disability rehabilitation and alcohol de-addiction. One of our flagship 105 programs is home-based rural palliative care program which has benefited numerous patients 106 with terminal illness ever since it was initiated in 2005. Our grass root workers continued to 107 do home visits to provide home care, monitor blood pressure and blood sugar, and to educate 108 the community about COVID-19. However, we had stopped our mobile clinics to reduce the 109 urban-rural transmission of infection. As there can be considerable variation in the 110 seroprevalence based on geographical setting and density of the population, knowledge of 111 seroprevalence in this community help us to conduct a risk-benefit analysis of certain 112 services like mobile clinics, which improves access to medical care at the cost of spreading 113 the virus to the rural community. Hence, we designed a community-based cross-sectional 114

FIGREF6.text: 121and 105 gram panchayats which are village administrative units(Fig.1). Each gram 122 panchayats has a cluster of10-15 villages [11]. According to the Indian Census 2011, the 123 population was9,90,923, and the sex-ratio was 945 females for every male, which is lesser 124 than the state of the average of 973. The district has a population density of 441 inhabitants 125 per square kilometre. The villagers are dependent on farming and farming related activities 126 such as cattle rearing for their income. However, the advent of Special Economic Zone (SEZ)127    and Bangalore International Airport in this district, service and Information technology 128 industries are also booming in the past few years[12]. Health care in the district is delivered129 through the Government health system and private practitioners. Apart from primary health 130 care, BBH also established strong community connections through the formation of village 131 health committees and linking with the rural self-government. Pictorial map of Bangalore rural district 133 Study design and sample size 134 We designed a cross-sectional seroepidemiological survey in Bangalore rural district based 135 on the recommendation of WHOas the most appropriate study design [13]. A serosurvey 136 from a densely populated slum in Mumbai, India reported a seroprevalence 57%, and we 137 assumed a seroprevalence of 30% (lower risk of transmission in rural areas compared to 138 slums) in the rural district. We calculated a minimum sample size of 504 with 5% absolute 139 and a design effect of 1.5 [14].

FIGREF7.text: District consists of four sub-districts which are further divided into 142 grampanchayats which are village administrative units. From the four sub-districts, we 143 randomly chose two grampanchayats. In each grampanchayat, a village which is centrally 144 located was chosen as a sampling unit based on convenience, and a kiosk was set up in one of 145 the trusted community spaces in each village. Our community health workers invited people 146

FIGREF8.text: 160 education, comorbidities such as diabetes, hypertension, lung disease and cancer), history of 161 exposure to COVID-19 infection (history of being diagnosed as COVID-19 case, interaction 162 and household contacts with persons with confirmed COVID-19), any history of COVID-19 163 related symptoms a month before the survey. After the completion of the interview, our 164 phlebotomists collected 5ml of blood from each participant via venepuncture in a plain 165 vacutainer. They transported it to BBH laboratory within 5 hours, maintaining the cold chain.

FIGREF10.text: 168assay, an electro chemiluminescent immunoassay using a recombinant protein representing 169 the nucleocapsid (N) antigen for the determination of high-affinity antibodies (including IgG) 170 against SARS CoV2[15]. This assay employs a cut-off index (COI) that is automatically calculated from two calibration standards-a COI of 1.0 or more is considered 172 reactive/positive, and a COI less than or equal to 1.0 is reported as nonreactive/negative. The 173 assay sensitivity and specificity were reported to be 97·2% (95·4-98·4) and 99·8% (99·3-174 100) respectively, in samples taken 30 days or more post symptom onset.[16] A unique 175 identification number was used to link the interview information and laboratory results.

The frequency of characteristics of the survey participants was described. 179 Unadjusted seroprevalence of COVID-19 IgG antibody was reported in per cent with 95% 180 confidence interval (CI). We used rural area figures of Karnataka from the Sample 181 Registration System (SRS) statistical report 2018 to calculate weights for reporting age-and-182 gender standardised seroprevalence [17] (S.1

FIGREF12.text: Case-to-undetected-infections ratio (CIR), was calculated as a ratio of the number of reported184 RT-qPCR-confirmed COVID-19 cases two weeks before the imitation of serosurvey to the 185 number of people who have antibodies in our study. This was based on an earlier study 186 reported median seroconversion times for total antibodies, IgM and then IgG at day-11, day-187 12 and day-14, respectively based on hospitalised patients and seroconversion for IgG and 188

FIGREF13.text: 189 time from infection to death, we considered the reported number of fatalities after three 190 weeks of the survey to estimate the plausible range of the infection fatality ratio (IFR) [16]. It 191 was calculated as the number of deaths reported upon the total number of people with high-192 affinity antibodies per 10000 infections. We used a projected population of 2020 Bangalore 193 rural district using 2011 census data prepared by Directorate of Economics and statistics, 194 Bangalore 2013 to calculate all these parameters. [20] The association of seroprevalence with 195 comorbid conditions and socio-demographic characteristics was tested using chi-square tests. 196 Ethical consideration 197 The Ethics Committee on Bangalore Baptist Hospital approved the survey protocol on 30 198June 2020. Written informed consent was obtained from the participants, and the test results 199 were communicated to them.

FIGREF14.text: participants were almost equally distributed in four taluks (Doddaballapur -28.6%, 202 Devanahalli -23.5%, Nelamangala -25.7%, Hoskote -20.2%) of Bangalore rural district. The 203 mean age was 47.0 +/ 16.4 years, and the majority were men (52.3%). Most people (86.0%) 204 had less than 12 years of education, and 28.4 % were either not working or homemakers. 205 Hypertension (20.2%) and diabetes (16.9 %) were reported as the most common 206 comorbidities. (Table. 1). Among 509 individuals, 7/509 (1.37%) had at least one symptoms 207 suggestive of COVID-19 in the last three months before the interview, 5/509 ( 0.98%) 208 reported a history of an infected family member, and none of them gave a history exposure 209 to an infected person in the past or tested positive for COVID

FIGREF15.text: infection in Bangalore rural district was 96,874 (95% CI 78638-243 123086) during two weeks before the beginning of the study (17 September to 1 October 244 2020). When we adjusted for sensitivity and specificity of the test kit, the seroprevalence was 245 6.1% (95% CI 4.02 -8.17) and the cumulative number of infections was 69,521 (95% CI 246 45815 -92315).247 The cumulative number of RT-PCR confirmed cases till 2 October was 10054 in Bangalore 248 rural district. The study estimated 7 (96854/10054) undetected infected individuals for every 249 RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction) confirmed case, i.e., case-to-250 undetected-infections ratio (CIR) of 1:7 and CIR could range from 1:4.5 to 1:9. Based on 251 age-gender adjusted seroprevalence rate, the Infection Fatality Rate (IFR) was calculated as 252 12.38 per 10000 infections as on 22 October 2020 in Bangalore rural district. revealed that a large proportion of the rural population remains susceptible to 259 infection and far from reaching the seroprevalence required for herd immunity. A serosurvey 260 from Karnataka during the same period (3-16 September) has reported a sightly higher 261 seroprevalence of 15.2% in the same district [21]. The variation can be attributed to samples 262 collected from multiple settings, including hospital settings and among the high-risk group. 263 The low prevalence in this rural district is in contrast to an earlier unpublished study by the 264 same investigators that was conducted ina dense urban slum in Bangalore City, which 265 showed a seroprevalence of 57%.[9] This is expected as the participants in the current study, 266 lived in sparsely populated villages, in well-ventilated houses and with the privilege of less 267 polluted air. When the government imposed lockdown, the adequacy of minimal resources 268 for sustenance and the self-reliance of the villages, reduced travel to cities a minimum. These 269 factors would have limited the spread of the infection.

FIGREF17.text: contributes to the body of evidence regarding the virus, its spread and the future implications 341 in the rural context. The study being conducted by researchers who knows the population 342 closely is an added advantage as the results are discussed in relation to the contextual 343 realities.

FIGREF18.text: a low seroprevalence of COVID 19 infection among rural population in a district 351 of South India, six months after the index case. The age-old public health measures of low 352 population density, good housing, adequate ventilation, hygiene measures combined with the 353 public, private and local health leadership limited the spread of an infectious respiratory viral 354 pathogen in this low resource setting.Since more than three fourth of the rural population 355 remains susceptible to COVID-19, sustaining public health measures and promoting access to 356 vaccination is of utmost importance to safeguard the health this population as severe COVID 35719 can be overtly burdensome owing to poor tertiary healthcare landscape of the rural setting.

TABREF1.text: . The unadjusted seroprevalence among participants with hypertension and diabetes was 16.3% seropositivity was not significant. Among seropositive individuals, one participant reported a history of a family member being positive in the last three months before the interview. The

TABREF2.text: We found age and comorbidities were not significantly associated with seropositivity. under control. We could imply that the efforts to sensitise the public regarding COVID19 by the government and private sectors in sensitisation have played a valuable role.We estimated an IFR of 12.8 per 10000 infections or 0.13%, which is comparable to what is reported from the Indian subcontinent ( 0.27-1.03) and other countries like USA (0.12-0.2%) Iran (0.08-0.12%), Brazil and Spain (1%)[8,21,24]. Estimating IFR is a challenge as it will depend on infection rate (seroprevalence) and the robustness of system capturing mortality.Both variables have estimation challenges of varying degrees in different parts of India. Since there are only a handful of studies estimating seroprevalence, we have only limited studies to compare. IFR reported in a study conducted in a Bangalore slum during the same period was absurdly low (0.03%), which can be attributed to under-reporting of deaths rather than reduced fatality in urban slums [9].We could draw several implications from the findings of the study. First and foremost, rural areas succeeded in halting the spread of infection to a greater extent as compared to cities.However, rural areas are challenged by the poor health system and low cash economy, distancing itself from urbanisation reaped overall health benefits to people in villages, in terms of the number of infections. This is a reminder that guarded urbanisation preserving the natural ecosystem is an essential determinant of health.Secondly, strict containment strategies like lockdown curbed infection without profound livelihood implication sin this rural setting. This was possible because of the strength of the local economy and reduced inequities. The villages had enough seasonal grains (ragi, a millet), homegrown vegetables and dairy products for nourishment. Since the population density was less, there was enough water for the increased demand for handwashing, clean air to breathe, and physical distancing was a practical possibility. Strong social connections, a powerful rural disposition added value during COVID-19 infections. Neighbourhoods took care of infected households with food and essential medicines and arranged for a referral if they need hospital support.Thirdly, low seroprevalence should be looked in two ways. One way to look at this 322 'achievement', success in preventing the spread and the other way to look at it as 323 'responsibility' due to susceptibility. Since we assume that other villages in India have similar or a slightly lesser seroprevalence, we need to keep in mind' huge susceptible burden' as 68.84% of India's population live in villages according to the census (2011)[25]. This has potential to staggering peaks and gives a warning signal for policymakers about the possibilities of multiple waves of the pandemic. In this context, discussion on sustaining
